reviews.advice: Increase compensation to retent talents; reduce in kind benefits and translate to cash flows
reviews.cons: Long working hours and medium attractive pay and benefits
reviews.pros: Amazing culture, fast paced and steep learning curve. Good for multi taskers with out going personality and whos keen to develop. Opportunities are flexible and open as long as you work hard. Good in kind benefits eg company events, happy hours, travel opportunities

reviews.cons:
This is a terrible company. They treat their staff like spare parts. If you have a problem/ question you will receive a generic email from robotic staff. They don't bother to read your messages and will send you the same useless reply every time. 

Total blame culture against teachers. Numerous technology issues with their platform- always the teachers fault. Their codes for technical problems say it all really. You have SSP for student side problem, TTP for teacher technical problem and TSP which is also a teacher side problem- who knows what the difference is but both dock your pay and both fail to acknowledge any failure with the company technology. Added to that there is ZERO technical support. 

You also need to fill out a tech report if you can't enter class (it happens often) and despite that you still get an accusatory email that says you failed to attend class and you then need to follow up with further defense to prove that you weren't tardy. 

The teachers are made to jump through hoops to fill out an invoice only to be met with discrepancies anyway. You then waste an hour of your time each month re-checking your invoice, because it is so complicated. So why waste our time- just pay us. 

The hours are also incredibly unreliable. You can request 20 hours across the week, and get a random allocation (students don't choose you, the company allocates you randomized slots)  of 6 hours across six different days with 1-2 hours between classes, for example. Often a complete waste of  a day/ evening for what might be $5/$10. 

If students don't come to class you don't get paid. You have the option of completing writing corrections but they are tedious and take much longer than the 40 minute class would have. 

I would avoid them like the plague if you have other options. Lowest paid in the industry too, and you get an insulting $1 pay rise after a year in service. This company will kill your soul.
reviews.pros: They pay on time. You get to teach adults. That is it!

reviews.advice: Hire people with experience for both management and other staff roles. Screen all staff members, especially course leaders.
reviews.cons: Working from 8am to 10pm in Junior Residential Dublin. Pay works out at about €5 an hour. Management do nothing when children misbehave and break EF rules and Irish law. You might be lucky and get a good group of kids, but the majority have never heard the word no in their lives. Management do nothing to resolve issues and allow big issues to continue for weeks.
reviews.pros: There are no pros to working here.
reviews.summary: Do not work for this company

reviews.advice: Let your staff grow outside of the sales world!
reviews.cons: VERY sales minded. In an entry level (sales position) you are just focused on sales and your direct manager is just focused on numbers, thus there is not many possibilities to know about other areas of a business.
reviews.pros: Lots of autonomy taking decisions concerning the zones you manage. Sales minded and great environment full of young people.

reviews.advice:
You need to treat staff with more respect, you need to improve training and ensure that your Senior Teachers, DoS’s and Production Managers are qualified to do the job. Giving people promotions because they are stuck in China and have no job prospects back home does not create a good management structure.

Let staff try and enjoy the experience of living in China, don’t force them to go to pointless training every month.
reviews.cons:
The only experience I have is of working in Shenzhen for several months, EF may be great in other cities (I doubt it though!!).

The pay is terrible compared to many other teaching jobs in China. Training is also poor, often delivered in your own school by unqualified ‘teachers’ barely able to string a sentence together. 

Most of the Senior Teachers, DoS’s and Production Managers appear to have been promoted on the basis they have stuck around as opposed to actually being qualified to do the job. As a result, when you have training for the region, it will inevitably be a complete waste of time and you will come away with no more knowledge than when you went in!!!

A very important point is that foreign teachers already in Shenzhen never join EF, EF relies on glossy brochures to attract new people typically from the USA. Foreign teachers already in Shenzhen (and probably the rest of China) already know what EF is like and avoid it like the plague. They’d rather get paid more and work less hours at proper schools.

Long working hours from Friday to Sunday also become tiresome. Your last class will finish at 9:10pm on Friday and your first class will begin on Saturday at 9:00am. A very quick turn around time. During the week working hours are ok, you will have two days off mid-week such as Monday and Tuesday.

You will get LESS HOLIDAYS than everybody else, if a public holiday lasts 7 days, you will get 5 days off!! It is extremely frustrating and shows a complete contempt for and lack of respect for staff. Also, during the holidays you will be given forced ‘admin’ days, the school is effectively closed but you have to go to work and do nothing all day. It feels that EF likes to have a high degree of control over its staff just for the sake of it.

Exceptionally high staff turnover due to the above mentioned. At my school, staff rarely renew their contracts, it is impossible to when you consider the low pay, long office hours and terrible ‘leadership’.

At the end of the day EF is a business, as long as your students are happy and having fun and as long as their parents continue to pay, nobody cares what you do in the classroom. I’ve seen ‘teachers’ unable to teach, with terrible grammar, but they are good entertainers, like a clown!! If you are a good entertainer, then perhaps you will do well here.

If you have worked as a proper teacher back home, or in a decent, corporate job, you will struggle at EF. It is better suited to young graduates with little or no working experience.

There are no opportunities to travel as you work so much and have very few holidays. If you want to be able to travel and experience China you need to work at a public school as the holidays there are long. If you work at a training center like EF, your busiest times are when public schools have holidays.

During the busier times your schedule will be a nightmare. My schedule this summer was working from 8:30am- 12-30pm and then 5:00pm - 8pm or 9pm. In between the class times you may have more pointless admin where you have to sit in the office with no work to do twiddling your thumbs. 

Seriously, any positive reviews for EF China cannot be genuine. I have not spoken to any local staff or foreign teachers that have actually enjoyed working at EF.
reviews.pros: Flight and hotel for first 10 days are paid for by EF which enables a smooth transition from your own country to China. The initial training is fairly decent as well. Visa process is smooth.

reviews.advice:
1. Push communication
2. Don't give brand new teachers summer/winter classes
3. Train local staff on disabled children
reviews.cons:
I'm going to start with the reason why I quit first. I had a 2 severely autistic children in one of my classes. I'm not a special education teacher. They should not be in my class, they are not befitting from it, and its a major distraction from the rest of the class because either I or the TA have to continuously manage them. One child couldn't even speak and would continuously shout in class and try to run out of the room. One day we didn't even have TA's, and I literally couldn't teach my class because I had to spend the entire class time trying stop this kid from running out, and I got 9 other kids I need to manage. I've been trying to communicate with staff for months about this problem and they either don't understand what autism is or they're too reluctant to give refunds to parents because it looks bad for sales. Here sales are everything.

Communication is horrible. I'll be expected to do demo's but the demo materials on the IWB won't work, of course no one will tell me this before I enter the room so I have to improvise the entire lesson on the spot. Or maybe there will be no class scheduled on Omni, and your PA will approach you and tell you that you actually do have class now and you have to rush to your classroom and make something up on the spot or your class and coteachers class will magically swap on omni and the PA will not tell you whats happening. Or guess what? You now have a Life Club that just magically appeared on  your schedule. Dosen't matter if you never did one before, have no idea what it is, and when you ask they just tell you to ask the TA's and then realize I have to come up with a bunch of games, dances lead some trick or treat through the school and a craft. It went pretty badly and it made me late for my next class because of how close it was scheduled to it. Maybe, I don't know, ask if I can actually do it first?

 Demos are essentially extra classes we teach to prospective students. A lot of teachers disliked doing them on grounds that they are teachers and are not interested in sales, but I didn't mind doing demo classes.  Over and over again, however, I had demo's with only one student. When its like that if feels like a waste of time.



I've never worked at a place with such low morale and turnover before. When I first arrived there was 4 foreign teachers quitting at once. None of them had much good to say about the company and one of them, a senior teacher, was tasked with training me. After that nearly every other foreign teacher quit over the next few months, making me, after one other guy the oldest foreign teacher there. The other new hire that came to the school with me also quit before her probation ended because she was so overwhelmed with summer classes.

Instead of getting properly trained, eg. co-teaching, sitting in on classes I will be taking over I had a full load of summer courses instead and felt like I had no idea what I was doing. Then when they ended, and all the teacher I mentioned before quit, I got all their normal classes in addition to the PTC's, assessments, achievement ceremonies I had no idea how to do, I just had to figure it out.

Pay is very low, career advancement is painfully slow, you will get better work offers in China, and with staff that listen but don't do much its hard to want to stay with EF.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for providing this feedback about your experience working at EF. We understand how challenging it can be to manage a class of young learners and are continually working on communications and other initiatives to ensure that teachers are given the support and resources to successfully manage the classroom. We will also follow-up with relevant management on the issue of managing classes where there may be students with different learning needs. Thank you again for bringing this to our attention and for your detailed feedback.

reviews.pros: Flights and accommodations are OK. I enjoyed the majority of staff and teachers I worked with.

reviews.advice:
Hire REAL MANGERS. not staff that are  merely upgraded
anything less than 18K a month is exploitation
reviews.cons:
the salary is way below the average salary. almost half of what you can ask for.
the workload was too much. the people in charge were useless obviously had no managerial experience which is why most got fired
reviews.pros:
Good offices
colleagues were great to work with
location is great.
reviews.summary: Good start when you dont know much

reviews.advice:
Improve organisation of centres
Ensure adequate space and facilities are present in  centres
reviews.cons:
Poor organisation
Deal with students from many different cultures so naturally, conflicts will arise
Left to ensure that the students enjoy themselves without the help of management or paid activities
reviews.pros:
Very generous pay when  worked out on hourly basis
Meet great people
Work isn't too stressful
Good earner for a summer job in between college semesters etc

reviews.advice: Improve flexibility of hours/shifts and salaries.
reviews.cons:
The hours are somewhat antisocial so you end up having limited social life (i.e. only seeing other teachers). 
The pay was in the mid-range of similar positions at other companies in the same city.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your post. We are very happy to hear that you had a positive onboarding experience from start to finish. As a company, we are very proud of our comprehensive onboarding program. We wish you continued success in the next step of your career.

reviews.pros:
Their onboarding training was very comprehensive, and was followed up with regular monitoring. 
They were very thorough in all the visa and work permit paperwork.

reviews.advice: Work on keeping the great employees you have and maybe more of them will be inclined to stay.
reviews.cons:
-No focus on employee retention
- Would rather hire a bunch of young people straight out of college 
-A fun 'first job' but quickly gets boring 
-Constantly asking for more from employees without offering more pay, more incentives
reviews.pros:
Fun people
Nice office 
Beer fridge
reviews.summary: Not what it's cracked up to be
